header.title: 9.6 Trillion Pesos Under the Microscope
header.subtitle: A Comprehensive Analysis of Mexican Federal Procurement, 2002-2025
header.lead: Between 2002 and 2025, the Mexican federal government awarded {{totalContracts}} public procurement contracts worth a combined {{totalValue}} — roughly {{totalValueUSD}}. This report presents the findings of a systematic, AI-driven analysis of every one of those contracts. Using a 16-feature per-sector risk model validated against fifteen documented corruption cases, we identified patterns consistent with fraud, collusion, and abuse in contracts worth an estimated {{valueAtRisk}} — {{pct}}% of all procurement value. These findings do not constitute proof of wrongdoing. They are statistical signals that warrant investigation.

keyFindings.title: Key Findings
items: 71% of federal contracts skip open competition — a structural feature of Mexican procurement, not an exception
Every December for 23 years, spending spikes 1.33× — budget dumping repeated across every administration
7.9% of total procurement value is flagged as high or critical risk, concentrated in a handful of dominant vendors
Our AI model validated at 96% accuracy: it would have flagged IMSS fraud 8 years before the scandal broke

sSystem.label: Context
sSystem.title: How Public Procurement Works — And Why It Matters Now
sSystem.intro: To understand what the data shows, it helps to know what the data is supposed to show. Mexico's federal procurement system operates under the Ley de Adquisiciones, Arrendamientos y Servicios del Sector Público (LAASSP), first enacted in 2000. The law establishes three types of contracting procedures, each with different transparency requirements. Above certain thresholds, federal agencies are legally required to use open competitive bidding. The system was designed to ensure public money flows to the best offer — not the most connected one.
sSystem.proc1When: Required above legal threshold (~$300K MXN for goods and services)
sSystem.proc1How: Public notice, unlimited bidders, minimum 20-day ad period. Mandatory publication on COMPRANET. Most transparent procedure.
sSystem.proc2When: Allowed for mid-range contracts, or when open bidding is deemed impractical
sSystem.proc2How: At least 3 vendors invited. Shorter process, limited to invited parties. Less public scrutiny.
sSystem.proc3When: Below threshold, emergencies, sole-source situations, or — under the 2025 law — when content is classified
sSystem.proc3How: No competition. Agency selects vendor directly. Reported after the fact, often with minimal detail.
sSystem.gapTitle: The Gap Between Law and Practice
sSystem.gapText: The law requires open competition above threshold. In practice, 71% of all federal contracts across 23 years skip open competition — either through direct award or restricted tender. Three mechanisms explain the gap: contracts are split to stay below thresholds (threshold splitting); emergency exceptions are invoked broadly; and the 2025 reform now explicitly allows direct awards when contract content is classified as reserved information, embedding opacity directly into the legal framework.
sSystem.oversightText: Three institutions were designed to enforce transparency. COMPRANET (1996–2025) was the mandatory federal procurement portal — every purchase above threshold was required to be published there. INAI was the independent transparency watchdog — citizens and journalists could appeal to it when agencies refused information requests. The ASF (Auditoría Superior de la Federación) is the federal audit court with independent review powers over contract execution. Of these three, only ASF retains full operational independence.
sSystem.crisisText: In August 2024 — before any law changed — 1.9 million contracts from 2012–2023 (4.7 trillion MXN) were silently removed from COMPRANET's public interface. In December 2024, INAI was constitutionally abolished and replaced by 'Transparencia para el Pueblo,' an agency housed within the executive branch it was created to oversee, operating on roughly 2% of INAI's former budget. In April 2025, Congress voted 68–23 to formally abolish COMPRANET and replace it with ComprasMX — a platform that shares its architecture with Tianguis Digital, the procurement system used during Sheinbaum's time as Mexico City head of government, which disclosed no contracts in that period. The new law includes a 5-year data retention clause that analysts estimate would eventually remove records of 2.6 million contracts worth 9.9 trillion MXN from official public access.
sSystem.crisisNote: The 3.1 million contracts in this database were captured before these changes. They represent a historical record that is becoming progressively harder to access through official channels. Independent archiving is the only safeguard.
sSystem.sources: Sources: Mexicanos Contra la Corrupción y la Impunidad (MCCI) · Fundar Centro de Análisis e Investigación · IMCO · Proceso · Diario Oficial de la Federación (April 16, 2025)

sPatterns.title: Three Systemic Patterns
sPatterns.intro: Before asking which contracts are suspicious, the data reveals something more fundamental: three structural patterns that pervade Mexican federal procurement across all administrations, sectors, and decades. These are not anomalies — they are the system.

p1DirectAward.label: Pattern 01
p1DirectAward.name: The Direct-Award Economy
p1DirectAward.desc: {{pct}}% of all federal contracts are awarded without open competition — either as direct awards or restricted tenders. Conventional anti-corruption frameworks treat direct awards as red flags. The Mexican data reveals something more troubling: <bold>competition itself is largely absent</bold>. There is no tender to rig when there is only one bidder.
p1DirectAward.note: This is not a recent anomaly. The non-competitive rate has remained above 65% across all five administrations since 2002.

p2December.label: Pattern 02
p2December.name: The December Rush
p2December.desc: Every December, contract awards spike 1.33× above the monthly average — a pattern that has repeated without interruption across 23 years and five administrations. It is driven by the fiscal year's use-it-or-lose-it budget logic: agencies rush to commit unspent funds before December 31. Rushed procurement is compromised procurement.
p2December.note: In years with sufficient data, the spike was statistically significant in 3 of 10 measured years. The pattern is structural; its corruption impact is compounded by deadline pressure.

p3Concentration.label: Pattern 03
p3Concentration.name: The Value Concentration Paradox
p3Concentration.desc: 7.9% of total procurement value sits in contracts flagged as high or critical risk — and that risk concentrates in a vanishingly small number of dominant vendors. The vendors who capture the most value are also the most statistically anomalous. Concentration is not just a symptom of corruption; it is its strongest statistical predictor.
p3Concentration.note: Price volatility — vendors with wildly varying contract sizes — is the #1 corruption signal. The corruption is in who keeps winning, not in which procedure type was used.

s1.title: The Threat
s1.p1: Of the {{totalValue}} in analyzed procurement, an estimated <bold>{{valueAtRisk}}</bold> — {{pct}}% of all value — sits in contracts flagged as high or critical risk. To put this in context, Mexico's entire annual federal education budget is approximately 400 billion pesos. The value at risk in this dataset is roughly equivalent to {{years}} years of education spending.
s1.p2: Risk is not evenly distributed. The bulk of flagged value concentrates in a small number of high-value contracts from dominant vendors in health, infrastructure, and energy. The remaining {{remainingPct}}% of value falls in medium or low risk categories — not clean, but less urgently suspicious.
s1.p3: A counterintuitive finding: <bold>direct awards are not the primary risk signal</bold>. In our model, direct award procedures carry only a slightly positive coefficient (+0.182), providing minimal discriminating signal. The real red flag is not how a contract is awarded, but <bold>who keeps winning</bold>. Price volatility — vendors with wildly varying contract sizes — is the strongest single predictor of corruption in v5.0.

s2.title: The Proof
s2.p1: Any model can flag contracts. The question is whether it flags the right ones. We validated our model against {{cases}} documented Mexican corruption cases spanning {{contracts}} contracts from {{vendors}} matched vendors. These are not hypothetical — they are cases that led to criminal investigations, arrests, and public scandal. The model was asked: would you have flagged these?
s2.p2: The answer: <bold>yes, in {{detectionRate}}% of cases</bold> (at medium risk or above). The model achieves an AUC-ROC of {{auc}}, meaning it correctly ranks a randomly chosen corrupt contract above a clean one {{aucPct}}% of the time.
s2.earlyWarning: <accent>Early warning value:</accent> The model would have raised alarms on IMSS ghost company contracts as early as 2008 — <italic>eight years</italic> before the scandal became public in 2016. For Segalmex, the earliest flagged contracts predate the 2020 investigation by several years.
s2.p3: The strongest detections occur in cases involving <bold>concentrated vendors in health and agriculture</bold> — IMSS (99.0%), Segalmex (94.3%), COVID-19 procurement (91.8%). These cases share a common pattern: a small number of vendors capturing outsized market share. Detection is weakest for cases involving <bold>bribery and conflict of interest</bold> — Grupo Higa (33.3%), Cyber Robotic (43.2%) — where corruption operates through relationships rather than statistical patterns in the procurement data itself.

s3.title: Where the Risk Concentrates
s3.p1: Three sectors dominate the risk landscape. <bold>Health</bold> (Salud) accounts for the largest volume — {{healthContracts}} contracts worth {{healthValue}}. <bold>Infrastructure</bold> carries fewer contracts but enormous per-unit values. <bold>Energy</bold> combines both volume and value in a sector with structural concentration (few vendors can serve Pemex and CFE).
s3.riskLabel: ESTIMATED VALUE AT RISK BY SECTOR

health.name: Health
health.text: The largest sector by contract volume. Home to the IMSS ghost company network and COVID-19 procurement fraud — two of the three largest corruption cases in the dataset. The sheer scale means even a modest risk rate translates to enormous absolute value at risk.

infrastructure.name: Infrastructure
infrastructure.text: Relatively low risk rate, but dominated by mega-contracts from firms like CICSA and ICA. A single flagged infrastructure contract can be worth more than thousands of smaller flagged contracts in other sectors combined.

agriculture.name: Agriculture
agriculture.text: Only 3.2% of total procurement value but disproportionately represented in high-risk contracts. The Segalmex scandal (LICONSA, DICONSA) exposed systematic fraud in food distribution — a sector where oversight was historically weak.

s4.title: Who Is Involved
s4.p1: The top 10 vendors by contract value collectively hold <bold>{{totalValue}}</bold> in procurement. Among them, two are confirmed participants in documented corruption cases. Several others carry risk scores above 0.20, indicating statistical patterns consistent with the corruption cases in our training data.
s4.p2: It is important to distinguish <bold>high value from high risk</bold>. CICSA (Operadora CICSA) ranks #1 by total contract value with {{topValue}}B MXN, but carries a moderate risk score. In contrast, vendors with fewer but higher-risk contracts may represent more actionable investigation targets. The <shield></shield> icon marks vendors confirmed in documented corruption cases.

s5.title: The Network
s5.p1: Corruption rarely operates in isolation. Our co-bidding analysis identified <bold>8,701 vendors</bold> with suspicious bidding patterns — vendors that frequently appear in the same procurement procedures but rarely compete against each other. These patterns affected over <bold>1 million contracts</bold>.
s5.p2: Two key patterns emerge: <bold>cover bidding</bold>, where partners consistently submit losing bids to create the appearance of competition, and <bold>bid rotation</bold>, where vendors take turns winning in predictable patterns. Both are classic indicators of bid-rigging cartels documented by the OECD.
s5.p3: Institution concentration also plays a critical role. When a single vendor captures a disproportionate share of an institution's procurement budget, it creates dependency and reduces competitive pressure — conditions ripe for corruption. Our analysis measures this through the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) at the institution level.

s6.title: The Data
s6.p1: This analysis is built on COMPRANET, Mexico's federal procurement transparency portal. The data spans four distinct structures with dramatically different quality levels — a challenge that shapes everything from risk score reliability to network analysis capability.

a.note: Risk scores may be underestimated. Network analysis effectively impossible.

b.note: UPPERCASE text. 72.2% direct award rate. Vendor identification improving.

c.note: Mixed case. 78.4% direct award rate. Reliable for most analyses.

s6.trillionLesson: <accent>The trillion-peso lesson:</accent> A previous analysis of this data included 7 contracts with values exceeding 1 trillion pesos — obvious decimal point errors that destroyed all analytics. These contracts, if real, would have represented 12.5% of Mexico's entire federal budget each. We now reject any contract exceeding 100 billion MXN and flag contracts above 10 billion for manual review.
s6.p2: Amount validation is critical: Mexico's entire federal budget is approximately 8 trillion MXN annually. The largest legitimate PEMEX contracts are typically 1-5 billion MXN. Our validation rules ensure that data errors do not silently corrupt the analytics.

s7.title: Across Administrations
s7.p1: Corruption risk has proven remarkably persistent across political transitions. No administration has been immune, though the <italic>character</italic> of risk varies — from data quality limitations in the Fox era, to volume concentration under Peña Nieto, to the highest direct award rates under AMLO.

narratives.Fox: Earliest data period (Structure A) with lowest quality — 0.1% RFC coverage. Risk scores may be underestimated. Direct award data unavailable for this period.
narratives.Calderon: Contract volume doubled as COMPRANET modernized. The IMSS ghost company network began operations during this period, with earliest contracts dating to 2008.
narratives.Pena Nieto: Largest procurement volume of any administration. 73.4% direct awards. Period of the Odebrecht bribery scandal, La Estafa Maestra, and the Grupo Higa conflict of interest case.
narratives.AMLO: Highest observed risk rate and highest direct award percentage at 79.5%. The Segalmex and COVID-19 procurement scandals occurred during this administration.
narratives.Sheinbaum: Early data only (2025). The direct award rate stands at 66% — a slight decrease from López Obrador's 79.5%. But the administration's most consequential procurement decisions have not been in the contracts themselves. In April 2025, COMPRANET — the platform this entire analysis is built on — was abolished by Congress and replaced by ComprasMX. In December 2024, INAI was constitutionally eliminated. The new procurement law expands grounds for direct awards when information is classified, and the 5-year data retention clause threatens the long-term public record. Whether this represents modernization or structural opacity will be measurable as ComprasMX data becomes available for analysis.

s8.title: How We Know
s8.p1: The v5.0 model transforms procurement analysis from a weighted indicator checklist to a <bold>statistical risk scoring framework</bold>. Every contract receives a score measuring similarity to documented corruption patterns, derived from 16 features normalized against sector and year baselines using z-scores, with multivariate anomaly detection via Mahalanobis distance and logistic regression trained on {{contracts}} known-bad contracts.
s8.p2: <bold>Price volatility is the strongest single predictor</bold> — vendors whose contract amounts vary wildly across their portfolio are the most suspicious. This challenges the standard anti-corruption toolkit. Institution diversity and win rate round out the top three, while traditional indicators like single bidding and co-bidding provide little discriminating signal.

s9.title: What We Cannot See
s9.p1: Intellectual honesty demands we state what this analysis cannot do. A risk model is a lens, not an oracle. It amplifies patterns from historical data, which means it is blind to anything that doesn't resemble the past.

groundTruth.title: Ground Truth Concentration
groundTruth.text: While ground truth has been diversified to 15 cases across all 12 sectors, the three largest cases (IMSS, Segalmex, COVID) still contribute the majority of training contracts. The model excels at detecting concentration-based fraud but may underdetect novel corruption schemes.
groundTruth.mitigation: Adding 8+ cases in v6.0. Workaround: per-sector models reduce this bias.

dataQuality.title: Data Quality Degrades with Age
dataQuality.text: Structure A data (2002-2010) has only 0.1% RFC coverage, making vendor identification unreliable. Risk scores for this period may be underestimated, and network analysis is effectively impossible.
dataQuality.mitigation: For network analysis, filter to contracts from 2018+ (30%+ RFC coverage).

correlation.title: Correlation is Not Causation
correlation.text: A high risk score indicates statistical anomaly consistent with known corruption patterns — it does not constitute proof of wrongdoing. Some sectors (Defense, Energy) have structural reasons for vendor concentration that are not corrupt.
correlation.mitigation: Always cross-reference with ASF audit reports before publishing.

unknowns.title: Unknown Unknowns
unknowns.text: Novel corruption schemes that do not resemble the 15 documented cases will not be flagged by this model. The model detects what it has been trained to recognize — patterns from the past, not innovation in fraud.
unknowns.mitigation: ASF audit data integration is in the v6.0 roadmap.

s9.calibrationNote: This rate reflects thresholds calibrated to the OECD 2–15% international benchmark. Under alternative thresholds, the rate ranges from 2% to 23%. These are statistical signals for triage — not prevalence estimates of actual corruption.

s10.title: What Comes Next
s10.p1: This analysis is not an endpoint — it is a starting point for investigation. The model has identified where to look. The following steps would maximize the platform's impact on procurement integrity.

investigate.title: Investigate High-Concentration Vendors
investigate.description: Vendors with critical risk scores collectively hold over 1 trillion MXN in procurement. Start with the top 50 by risk-weighted value.

safeguards.title: Strengthen Competitive Safeguards
safeguards.description: The problem is not which procedure type is used, but who participates and wins. Focus oversight on vendor concentration rather than procedure classification.

diversify.title: Diversify Ground Truth
diversify.description: The model needs more training cases from infrastructure, defense, and technology sectors. ASF audit reports and Mexicanos Contra la Corrupción investigations are promising sources.

footer.quote: "There are things that cannot be measured in terms of victory or defeat."
footer.disclaimer: Risk scores are statistical indicators with confidence intervals. A high score indicates similarity to documented corruption patterns — it does not constitute proof of wrongdoing.
